video_caption: The video begins with a black screen that transitions to an animated logo featuring a cartoon character named Dr. Zack, who is dressed in a blue shirt, blue pants, and green shoes. The logo includes the text "Dr. Zack" and "Flat Earth Research" alongside an image of a globe with a green leaf. The scene then shifts to a YouTube video titled "Flat Earth | Problem Solved (Subtitulado)" by Dr. Zack, which has garnered 13,317 views. The video showcases various scenes, including a blue background with the text "made of five distinct layers," a sunset over a barren landscape, and a man in a suit speaking into a microphone with a laptop in front of him. The man, identified as Sandor Szekely AKA Dr. Wan, gestures with his hands while speaking. The video maintains a consistent theme of discussing flat earth theories, with the YouTube interface and related video thumbnails visible throughout. The video concludes with the man continuing to speak, emphasizing his points with hand gestures, while the YouTube interface and related video thumbnails remain visible.

The video begins with a man named Steve Torrence, who is seated in front of a laptop, holding a microphone, and appears to be speaking. The background is dark, and there is a blue overlay with text and graphics, including a diagram of a flat Earth model. The video is titled "Flat Earth Celestial Clock v3.31 - Tenerife, Spain (Star Trails 360°)" and is dated June 21, 2016. The scene transitions to a celestial clock display with various celestial bodies and their positions, including the sun, moon, and planets, with corresponding data such as altitude, airspeed, and distance. The next scene shows a close-up of the moon against a black background, with the text "CC v3.31 Do we know the moon is a sphere?" displayed at the bottom. The video then shifts to a different celestial clock display, this time showing a balloon reflection with the moon and sun, and various celestial data. The final scene features a flat Earth model with the moon and sun positioned above it, accompanied by text and data related to the celestial clock. Throughout the video, the YouTube interface is visible, with various related videos and thumbnails displayed on the right side of the screen.

The video begins with a serene view of a mountainous landscape under a clear sky, with the sun shining brightly. Text overlays provide astronomical data, including the positions and speeds of celestial bodies like the Sun, Moon, and planets, as well as details about the camera's altitude and the Sun's position relative to the Moon. The scene transitions to a black screen with the text "NOT US" in white, followed by another black screen with the text "NOT THEM" in white. The video then returns to the mountainous landscape, now with the sun partially obscured by the mountains, creating a dramatic effect. The text overlays continue to display astronomical data, with the date and time changing to indicate the passage of time. The video concludes with the sun fully obscured by the mountains, casting a shadow over the landscape, while the text overlays provide additional astronomical information.

The video begins with a simple illustration of a coastal cityscape, featuring a road with a green car, a tree, and buildings, including a church and a tower. The sky is clear, and the sea is calm. A man in a suit appears on the right side of the frame, looking at his phone. The scene transitions to include a blue arrow labeled "Atmosphere or Atmosplane" pointing towards the sea, indicating the concept of atmospheric refraction. The sun is then shown with two labels: "Real Sun" and "Apparent Sun," illustrating the apparent position of the sun due to atmospheric refraction. The man remains in the same position, observing the scene. The video continues to show the sun's apparent position, with the "Apparent Sun" being lower in the sky than the "Real Sun." The man is still looking at his phone, and the coastal cityscape remains unchanged. The video concludes with the sun setting below the horizon, leaving only a small portion of the sun visible above the water, while the man continues to observe the scene. The overall atmosphere of the video is educational, explaining the concept of atmospheric refraction and its effect on the apparent position of the sun.

The video begins with a cartoonish illustration of a cityscape by the sea, featuring a man in a suit standing on the right side, looking at his phone. Above the city, two suns are depicted, one labeled "HIGH" and the other "LOW," with arrows pointing towards them. The text "WHAT MAKES THE SUN GO DOWN AS IT MOVES AWAY FROM YOU?" appears at the top, prompting viewers to ponder the phenomenon. The scene transitions to a hand-drawn sketch of a sun with a face, followed by a return to the original cityscape illustration. The man remains in the same position, and the text reappears, now with an additional arrow labeled "5MILES" pointing from the man to the "LOW" sun, indicating distance. The video then introduces a large arrow spanning the width of the sea, labeled "7000MILES," illustrating the vast distance between the two suns. A hand giving a thumbs-up gesture appears in the bottom left corner, suggesting approval or understanding. The video concludes with the removal of the "HIGH" sun and the large arrow, leaving only the "LOW" sun and the man, emphasizing the concept of the sun's apparent movement and the distance involved.

The video begins with a white screen displaying the text "PERSPECTIVE WILL HELP BUT IT WILL NOT SOLVE THE PROBLEM" in bold black letters, accompanied by a small logo in the bottom left corner. The scene transitions to a colorful illustration featuring a man in a suit standing on a road, with a city skyline, a tree, and a sun in the background. The text "4000MILES" appears at the top, indicating a significant distance. The video then shifts to a white background with a hand-drawn map, highlighting various locations and paths with arrows and labels, suggesting a journey or route. Following this, an underwater view of a swimming pool lane is shown, with a light bulb icon floating above, symbolizing an idea or solution. The video continues with a white screen displaying the text "IF YOU, GUYS, CAN HELP" in black letters, followed by an email address "zikoworld123@gmail.com" in blue, and "DR. ZACK:" in red, indicating a call for assistance. The scene then transitions to an illustration of two glasses of water with red straws, demonstrating the refraction of light, accompanied by a person's head observing the phenomenon. The video concludes with a hand-drawn globe, emphasizing the global context of the narrative. Throughout the video, the logo remains visible in the bottom left corner, maintaining brand consistency.

The video begins with a black background featuring a vertical scale marked from 0° to 90°, with the labels "Without atmosphere (airless)" on the left and "With atmosphere" on the right. A white dot representing the sun is positioned at the 30° mark on the scale. Text on the left side of the screen provides details about the camera's altitude, vertical field of view, and the sun's altitude, elevation angle, and distance. As the video progresses, the white dot moves upwards along the scale, illustrating the apparent position of the sun with and without an atmosphere. The text updates to reflect changes in the camera's altitude and the sun's apparent distance. The scene transitions to a green, flat surface with a white dot at the center, representing the sun's position at a higher altitude. The text continues to provide updated information about the camera's altitude and the sun's apparent distance. The video then shifts to a blue background with a vertical scale from 0° to 90°, labeled "No atmosphere" on the left and "Atmosphere" on the right. The white dot representing the sun moves upwards along the scale, demonstrating the apparent position of the sun with and without an atmosphere. The text on the left side of the screen provides details about the sun's distance and apparent distance. The video concludes with the white dot at the 70° mark on the scale, illustrating the apparent position of the sun with an atmosphere.

The video begins with a computer screen displaying a diagram titled "Sun On The Flat Earth," illustrating the apparent path of the sun across a flat Earth model. The diagram includes various lines and angles representing the sun's movement, with labels such as "Apparent speed of the sun," "Real path of the sun," and "Apparent path of the sun." The scene transitions to a map interface showing solar data for a specific location, Qesm Al Wahat Ad Dakhilah, New Valley, with details like sunrise, sunset, and solar peak times. The map highlights the sun's path across the sky, with a red dot marking the location. The video then returns to the diagram, zooming in on specific angles and distances, such as "22.19°" and "35.40°," and the distance from the observer to sunset in the tropic of cancer. The diagram is further detailed with measurements and annotations, emphasizing the sun's apparent speed and path. The scene shifts to a real-life sunset over the ocean, with the sun partially submerged in the water, casting a warm orange glow across the sky and clouds. The video then transitions to a video game scene, depicting a rainy highway with vehicles driving under an overpass, surrounded by a misty, mountainous landscape. The video concludes with a return to the computer screen, showing the diagram with additional annotations and measurements, reinforcing the concept of the sun's apparent path on a flat Earth model.

The video begins with a view of a highway under an overpass, where various vehicles, including cars and trucks, are driving in both directions. The weather is overcast, and the road appears wet, suggesting recent rain. The scene is set in a mountainous area with trees and hills visible in the background. The camera then transitions to a screen displaying detailed astronomical information, including celestial coordinates, distances, and positions of planets and the moon. The text is presented in English, with some terms in Spanish, such as "Celestial Clock v3.1" and "Ground location to the Sun distance." The information includes data on the positions of Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, and Uranus, along with their respective altitudes and signs. The video concludes with this screen, providing a stark contrast to the dynamic highway scene.

The video features a time-lapse of a celestial event captured from Tenerife, Spain, with a detailed overlay of astronomical data. The camera is positioned on a rocky surface, possibly a lunar landscape, with a winding path leading into the distance. The sky transitions from a deep blue to a warm yellow, indicating the passage of time. The overlay includes information such as the date, time, and location, as well as the positions and altitudes of celestial bodies like the Sun, Moon, and planets. The Sun's position shifts across the sky, and the Moon's phase and position are also tracked. The video provides a comprehensive view of the celestial mechanics, with the camera capturing the movement of the Sun and Moon against the backdrop of the sky. The overlay text is in English, with some details in Spanish, and includes technical specifications of the camera used to capture the footage. The video offers a visually stunning and informative depiction of the celestial event, combining the beauty of the natural world with the precision of astronomical data.

The video showcases a series of frames from a celestial clock application, displaying detailed astronomical data and visualizations of the night sky. The background features a lunar landscape with craters and a horizon line, while the foreground is overlaid with text and graphical elements. The text provides information about the celestial clock's version, the ground location, and the current date and time in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). It also includes data on the Sun's position, size, and distance, as well as the Moon's diameter, position, and illumination percentage. The video captures the movement of celestial bodies, such as the Moon and planets like Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune, across the sky. The Moon's position and illumination percentage change over time, reflecting its phases. The camera angle and position remain fixed, offering a consistent view of the lunar surface and the dynamic celestial display. The video concludes with a frame showing the Moon's position and illumination percentage, along with the Sun's position and distance, providing a comprehensive overview of the celestial clock's functionality and the astronomical data it presents.

The video showcases a series of celestial clock displays, each capturing the movement of celestial bodies over time. The first set of frames features a night sky with star trails, indicating the Earth's rotation, and includes detailed information about the Moon's position, altitude, and distance from the Earth. The text overlays provide data such as the Moon's diameter, its position in the sky, and the camera's altitude and angle. The background shows a curved horizon, suggesting the footage was taken from a high vantage point, possibly a mountain or hilltop. The second set of frames continues this theme, with the celestial clock displaying the positions of the Sun, Moon, and planets like Mercury, Venus, and Mars, along with their respective distances and altitudes. The text overlays include the date and time, indicating the passage of time between the frames. The video concludes with a frame showing the Sun's position and the Sun-Moon angle, providing a comprehensive view of the celestial mechanics at play. The overall atmosphere is one of scientific observation and exploration, with the detailed text overlays serving as a guide to understanding the celestial events being depicted.

The video showcases a series of celestial observations, beginning with a view of Earth from space, highlighting the planet's curvature and cloud formations. The text overlay provides detailed astronomical data, including the date, time, and location of the observations, as well as the positions and distances of celestial bodies like the Moon and planets. The camera captures the Moon's movement across the sky, with the text updating to reflect its changing position and altitude. The video also includes a tracking of the Moon's position, with the text overlay displaying the Moon's diameter, altitude, and illumination percentage. The background transitions from a view of Earth to a starry sky, with the Moon's position and the positions of planets like Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune being tracked. The video concludes with a view of the Moon against the backdrop of the Earth's horizon, with the text overlay providing the Moon's position, altitude, and the Sun's angle relative to the Moon. The overall atmosphere is one of scientific observation and exploration of the cosmos.

The video begins with a computer screen displaying a spreadsheet and a graphical representation of celestial bodies and their positions. The spreadsheet contains data about various celestial objects, including their names, coordinates, and other astronomical details. The graphical representation shows a map with lines and markers indicating the positions of stars and planets, with labels such as "Arcturus," "Vega," and "Capella." The scene transitions to a more detailed view of the map, highlighting specific celestial objects and their positions relative to Earth. The video then shifts to a different graphical representation, showing a map with a compass rose and lines indicating the positions of celestial bodies in relation to a specific location on Earth. The map is labeled with the cardinal directions (N, S, E, W) and includes a scale in degrees. The video continues to display various graphical representations of celestial bodies and their positions, with labels and data points indicating their positions and movements. The final frames show a graphical representation of the sky with lines and markers indicating the positions of celestial bodies, with labels such as "Mercury," "Venus," "Mars," and "Jupiter." The video concludes with a view of the sky, showing the positions of celestial bodies and their movements over time, with labels and data points indicating their positions and movements. Throughout the video, the graphical representations are accompanied by text in Spanish, providing additional information about the celestial objects and their positions. The video provides a comprehensive overview of the positions and movements of celestial bodies in relation to Earth, using graphical representations and data points to illustrate their positions and movements over time.

The video begins with a black screen, gradually revealing a crescent moon in the night sky. The moon's surface becomes more visible, showcasing its craters and texture. The scene transitions to a map of the Earth, with the moon superimposed over it, indicating its position relative to the planet. The moon appears to move across the map, suggesting its orbit around the Earth. The video concludes with a black screen displaying the text "THANKS FOR WATCHING" in white capital letters, signaling the end of the video.
